places.name: Eiffel Tower
places.funFact: Did you know the Eiffel Tower grows in the summer? Heat causes the metal to expand, so the tower can grow by up to 15 cm!

places.name: Pyramids of Giza
places.funFact: The Great Pyramid was the tallest man-made structure in the world for over 3,800 years—until the Lincoln Cathedral was built in England in 1311!

places.name: Taj Mahal
places.funFact: It's said that Emperor Shah Jahan intended to build a second Taj Mahal in black marble as a mirror image, but was imprisoned by his son before he could start!

places.name: Sydney Opera House
places.funFact: Despite its name, the Sydney Opera House hosts more than just opera—it also offers theater, symphony, ballet, and film!

places.name: Christ the Redeemer
places.funFact: The statue is struck by lightning several times a year due to its position. It has its own lightning rod installed in the statue's head!

places.name: Stonehenge
places.funFact: Despite its age, Stonehenge still doesn't have a confirmed purpose. Some believe it could have been an ancient alien landing pad!

places.name: Machu Picchu
places.funFact: Machu Picchu wasn't discovered by the outside world until 1911, but locals knew about it all along. It's still a mystery why the Incas abandoned this architectural masterpiece.

places.name: Louvre Museum
places.funFact: With nearly 10 million visitors each year, the Louvre is the world's most visited museum. Yet, if you spent 60 seconds looking at each item, it would take you over 100 days to see everything!

places.name: Chichen Itza
places.funFact: During the spring and autumn equinoxes, a shadow falls on the pyramid in the shape of a serpent. As the day progresses, the serpent slithers down the steps!

places.name: Santorini
places.funFact: The whole complex of Santorini islands is still an active volcano, and probably the only volcano in the world with its crater in the sea!

places.name: Angkor Wat
places.funFact: Angkor Wat is the largest religious monument in the world, and it appears on Cambodia's national flag, making it the only flag in the world to feature a building!

places.name: Niagara Falls
places.funFact: Over six million cubic feet of water goes over the crest of the falls every minute during peak daytime hours. Talk about water pressure!

places.name: Petra
places.funFact: In the popular film 'Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade', Petra's Al Khazneh ('The Treasury') was depicted as the entrance to the final resting place of the Holy Grail!

places.name: Acropolis of Athens
places.funFact: The term 'acropolis' actually means 'high city' in Greek. While the Athens Acropolis is the most famous, there are many other cities in Greece with their own acropolis!

places.name: Sagrada Familia
places.funFact: The construction of Sagrada Familia started in 1882 and it's still not finished! The current target for completion is 2026—the centenary of Gaudí's death.

places.name: Moai Statues
places.funFact: There are nearly 900 moai statues on Easter Island, but did you know they have bodies too? Excavations have revealed that the heads are attached to bodies buried beneath the earth.

places.name: Pompeii
places.funFact: Although a disastrous event, the eruption that buried Pompeii preserved daily life items like furniture, artwork, and even food. It's like looking at a snapshot of Roman life!

places.name: Statue of Liberty
places.funFact: The seven spikes on the Statue of Liberty's crown represent the seven oceans and the seven continents of the world, indicating the universal concept of freedom.

places.name: Uluru (Ayers Rock)
places.funFact: Uluru is like an iceberg - most of it is below ground. The visible part is about 348 meters high, but it extends about 2.5 kilometers below the earth's surface!

places.name: Buckingham Palace
places.funFact: Buckingham Palace has 775 rooms, including 19 state rooms, 52 royal and guest bedrooms, 188 staff bedrooms, 92 offices, and 78 bathrooms!

places.name: Colosseum
places.funFact: The Colosseum could hold an estimated 50,000 to 80,000 spectators at its maximum capacity. It was used for gladiatorial contests, public spectacles, and even mock sea battles!

places.name: Matterhorn
places.funFact: Because of its shape, the Matterhorn was one of the last great Alpine peaks to be climbed. Also, the iconic Toblerone chocolate bar was modeled after it!

places.name: Lake Bled
places.funFact: The tradition at the island church is for a groom to carry his bride up the 99 steps to ensure a long and happy marriage. That's a workout with a reward!

places.name: Pena Palace
places.funFact: The Pena Palace was intentionally built to be visible from any point in the park, which is filled with exotic trees and has a system of secret paths and hidden tunnels.

places.name: Lake Baikal
places.funFact: Lake Baikal is so large that it is often mistaken for a sea. It contains more water than all of the Great Lakes in North America combined!

places.name: Casa Batlló
places.funFact: Casa Batlló is locally known as Casa dels ossos (House of Bones), due to its skeletal, organic quality. It's a prime example of Gaudí's famous modernist style!

places.name: Meteora
places.funFact: The name 'Meteora' means 'suspended in the air' or 'in the heavens above'. This is quite fitting, given the monasteries perch atop these gravity-defying rock formations!

places.name: Pena de Bernal
places.funFact: According to local lore, the monolith is believed to have mystical powers, and each spring equinox, people gather at its base to 'receive energy'. The climbing to the top also offers stunning views of the surrounding landscape!

places.name: Mount Bromo
places.funFact: The volcano belongs to the Bromo Tengger Semeru National Park. The name of Bromo derived from Javanese pronunciation of Brahma, the Hindu creator god.

places.name: Rainbow Mountain
places.funFact: This magnificent geological feature is said to have only recently emerged due to climate change and the melting of surrounding snow. Its rich colors are the result of sedimentary mineral layers exposed by erosion.

places.name: Museum Island
places.funFact: During World War II, many of the museums' items were stored for safety, and the buildings were heavily damaged, some even destroyed. They have since been reconstructed and restored to their former glory.

places.name: Golden Gate Bridge
places.funFact: Despite its name, the Golden Gate Bridge is actually painted 'international orange', not gold.

places.name: Mount Fuji
places.funFact: Mt. Fuji has an exceptionally symmetrical cone, which is snow-capped for about 5 months a year.

places.name: Tower of Pisa
places.funFact: The tower began to lean during construction in the 12th century, due to soft ground which could not properly support the structure's weight.

places.name: Sphinx
places.funFact: The Great Sphinx is one of the world's largest monuments, it is also one of the most recognizable, yet its origins and early history are still debated.

places.name: Rakotzbrücke (Devil's Bridge)
places.funFact: Rakotzbrücke is also known as the 'Devil's Bridge' due to a myth that such bridges were so miraculous they must have been built by Satan.

places.name: Cappadocia
places.funFact: The 'Fairy Chimneys', a strange geological feature, were formed by erosion of the volcanic tuff of Cappadocia and are one of the most iconic images of the area.

places.name: Chefchaouen
places.funFact: The tradition of painting the walls blue is said to have been introduced by Jewish refugees in the 1930s, and is maintained today because it keeps mosquitos away.

places.name: Mont Saint-Michel
places.funFact: Due to varying tides surrounding the island, Mont Saint-Michel can be both a peninsula and an island in a single day.

places.name: Eilean Donan Castle
places.funFact: The castle has appeared in numerous films and TV shows including 'Highlander', 'The World Is Not Enough', and 'Outlander'.

places.name: Schönbrunn Palace
places.funFact: The palace's gardens are a UNESCO World Heritage Site and have been open to the public since 1779.

places.name: Château de Chambord
places.funFact: The château features 426 rooms, 282 fireplaces, and 77 staircases. It is surrounded by a 20 square mile wooded park and game reserve maintained with red deer.

places.name: Wat Rong Khun
places.funFact: The White Temple is actually a work in progress. Although it was started in 1997, the whole project won’t be completed until 2070.

places.name: Salina Turda
places.funFact: In use since the 17th century, the mine is often considered one of the coolest underground places in the world.

places.name: Vernazza
places.funFact: The Santa Margherita d'Antiochia Church with its unique octagonal tower is a signature sight in Vernazza.

places.name: Huacachina
places.funFact: According to legend, the lagoon was created when a beautiful princess removed her clothes to bathe, but a young hunter startled her and she fled, leaving the pool of water she had been bathing in to become the lagoon.

places.name: Neuschwanstein Castle
places.funFact: The castle has appeared prominently in several movies and was the inspiration for Disneyland's Sleeping Beauty Castle.

places.name: European Parliament
places.funFact: The European Parliament is the only parliamentary institution of the EU that is directly elected by EU citizens every 5 years.

places.name: Great Ocean Road
places.funFact: The Great Ocean Road is the world's largest war memorial, built by returned soldiers between 1919 and 1932, and is dedicated to those killed during World War I.

places.name: Sigiriya
places.funFact: On a small plateau about halfway up the side of Sigiriya rock, a gateway in the form of an enormous lion was constructed. Today, only the lion's paws remain, giving the rock its name, 'Lion's Rock'.

places.name: Red Square
places.funFact: Despite its name, the square is not named for the red bricks of the buildings around it. In Russian, 'red' (krasnaya) used to mean 'beautiful', so it's actually 'Beautiful Square'.

places.name: Alesund
places.funFact: A devastating fire in 1904 destroyed much of Ålesund, but it was rebuilt in the Art Nouveau style, leading to its current unique aesthetic.

places.name: Pont des Arts
places.funFact: Due to safety concerns from the weight of the 'love locks', the city of Paris started removing them in 2015, but people continue to place locks on the nearby street light posts.

places.name: Ponte Vecchio
places.funFact: Ponte Vecchio was the only bridge across the Arno that the retreating Germans did not destroy during the World War II. Instead they blocked access by demolishing the medieval buildings at each end.

places.name: Ronda
places.funFact: The Puente Nuevo ('New Bridge') over El Tajo gorge took 34 years to build and claimed the lives of 50 builders.

places.name: Mostar
places.funFact: Diving off the Stari Most bridge is a 450-year-old tradition in Mostar. If you're brave enough, you can join local divers to plunge into the Neretva River below.

places.name: Alcatraz Island
places.funFact: During the 29 years it was in use, the jail held some of the most notorious criminals in American history such as Al Capone and Robert Franklin Stroud, the Birdman of Alcatraz.

places.name: Bixby Creek Bridge
places.funFact: The bridge was built in 1932 and is one of the tallest single-span concrete bridges in the world.

places.name: Trevi Fountain
places.funFact: It's tradition to throw a coin into the fountain to ensure a return trip to Rome.

places.name: Moulin Rouge
places.funFact: The Moulin Rouge is a symbol of the Bohemian lifestyle and remains a popular tourist destination, offering musical dance entertainment for visitors from around the world.

places.name: Cinque Terre
places.funFact: The Cinque Terre area is a very popular tourist destination and has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1997.

places.name: Hagia Sophia
places.funFact: The Hagia Sophia was built in 537 AD at the beginning of the Middle Ages and served as an Eastern Orthodox cathedral and seat of the Patriarch of Constantinople for nearly a thousand years.

places.name: Montmartre
places.funFact: Many artists, including Salvador Dalí, Claude Monet, Pablo Picasso and Vincent van Gogh, had studios or worked around the community of Montmartre.

places.name: Notre-Dame de Paris
places.funFact: Notre-Dame suffered severe damage during a fire in 2019, but restoration plans are underway and the cathedral remains one of Paris' most iconic sights.

places.name: Rijksmuseum
places.funFact: The museum has on display 8,000 objects of art and history, from their total collection of 1 million objects from the years 1200–2000, among which are some masterpieces by Rembrandt, Frans Hals, and Johannes Vermeer.

places.name: Fisherman's Bastion
places.funFact: Its seven towers represent the seven Magyar tribes that settled in the Carpathian Basin in 895.

places.name: Hallgrímskirkja
places.funFact: The church is named after the Icelandic poet and clergyman Hallgrímur Pétursson.

places.name: Edinburgh Castle
places.funFact: It was a royal residence until 1633 and is now one of Scotland's most popular tourist attractions.

places.name: Atomium
places.funFact: Tubes connect the spheres along the 12 edges of the cube and all eight vertices to the centre. They enclose escalators connecting the spheres containing exhibit halls and other public spaces.

places.name: Cloud Gate (The Bean)
places.funFact: The sculpture was selected during a design competition. Its highly reflective, curved surface distorts the reflections of people and buildings, creating unique perspectives and photographic opportunities.

places.name: One World Trade Center
places.funFact: The building, including its antenna, reaches a total height of 1,776 feet (541 m) - a deliberate reference to the year of the United States Declaration of Independence.

places.name: St. Basil's Cathedral
places.funFact: The building, now a museum, is officially known as the Cathedral of the Intercession of the Most Holy Theotokos on the Moat, or Pokrovsky Cathedral.

places.name: Marienplatz
places.funFact: The square is dominated by the New City Hall (Neues Rathaus). The monumental, 79 meters (259 ft) high city hall was built between 1867 and 1908 by Georg von Hauberrisser in a Gothic Revival architecture style.

places.name: Alexanderplatz
places.funFact: Alexanderplatz is still one of Berlin's major commercial areas, housing various shopping malls, department stores and other large retail locations.

places.name: Charles Bridge
places.funFact: The bridge is 621 meters long and nearly 10 meters wide, resting on 16 arches shielded by ice guards. It was the only means of crossing the river Vltava until 1841.

places.name: The Shard
places.funFact: Its construction began in March 2009 and was completed in November 2012. The Shard was developed to have multiple uses, described on the building plan as 'a vertical city where people can live, work and relax'.

places.name: Royal Palace of Madrid
places.funFact: The palace has 135,000 square metres (1,450,000 sq ft) of floor space and contains 3,418 rooms. It is the largest functioning royal palace and the largest by floor area in Europe.

places.name: Rialto Bridge
places.funFact: The present stone bridge, a single span designed by Antonio da Ponte, was completed in 1591 and was used to replace a wooden bridge that collapsed in 1524.

places.name: Bundestag
places.funFact: The Bundestag is housed in the Reichstag building in Berlin. The dome of the Reichstag is made of glass, symbolizing transparency in government.

places.name: Palace of Westminster
places.funFact: One of the most prominent features of the Palace of Westminster is the iconic clock tower, which houses the bell known as Big Ben.

places.name: United States Capitol
places.funFact: The Capitol was completed in the year 1800 and has been extended multiple times since then. The Capitol dome is an iconic feature of the Washington D.C. skyline.

places.name: Scott Monument
places.funFact: Completed in 1844, the Scott Monument stands 200 feet tall, and visitors can climb the 287 steps to the top for views over Edinburgh.

places.name: Nyhavn
places.funFact: The canal harbours many historical wooden ships, and it's one of the most iconic places in Denmark.

places.name: Belém Tower
places.funFact: The tower was commissioned by King John II to be part of a defence system at the mouth of the Tagus river and a ceremonial gateway to Lisbon.

places.name: Colmar
places.funFact: Colmar is renowned for its well-preserved old town and its numerous architectural landmarks. It's also known as the 'Capital of Alsatian Wine' - an area that is said to be the driest in France.
